values:
Aaaand ten months later I resurface, relatively unscathed, having survived a year living in very close proximity to people my own age in mostly sanitary conditions (the snowman in the bathtub was dubious, but nevermind).  

Freshman year is over and I survived like so many before and I am sure so many after.  Minnesota was in fact cold, but I love it nonetheless.  I have tentatively decided on majors and thus am taking summer school, the only way to graduate in anything even remotely resembling 4 years.  

I still spend most of my time planning trips.  Some (San Francisco) a bit more successful than others (Winnipeg), but all good fun, although this was sometimes provided solely by the fact that we could legally purchase liquor.  

I forgot how good a distraction livejournal was from studying.  I should employ this more often.   But as I do have a chem test tomorrow, I should get back to my significant figures and mole ratios and percent yields and other things.  Unbalanced equations call to me.

although it appears to be about 6 months since I did anything with this, reading my previous entry, I realize quite a lot is the same--namely, I will be gone in less than a week (although it is only 5 days this time) and I cut my hair again because I was bored.  However, this time I am going to the Frozen North instead of the Wet North so I suppose that counts as different.

I've quit my job for good; unemployment is better than I thought, although now I don't have the excuse of work to evade awkward hang-out-ing.  I try to use packing as my new excuse but, sadly, it doesn't have the same weight.  I have been packing, a bit in advance, and thus have no shirts worth wearing in my closets anymore, and have been reduced to lurching around like a badly dressed zombie as I tear my room apart looking for things like hangers, etc. 

My new computer came, it is yellow and has been christened Roger Mexico.  It is lightweight and clunks a lot less than the old one.  I got married (ish) to Julie and turned my mouth black with various black-frostinged things.  

I am all in a dither about what books to bring with me for my first semester; other than the dictionary, MLA handbook, u.s.w.  I know that realistically I will have no time to read or sleep or whatever but will feel awkward if I don't have anything on my bookshelf (which I still need to buy).  So far I have managed to stick half a dozen books in a box and then take them out again.
Wednesday night is going to be a long one.

Recovering from being comatose and on my back for the past 36 hours---inconveniently placed over a concert night, but not so inconveniently placed that it prevents me from fleeing the country (the mantra of 6days6days has burned itself into my brain). In a fit of pique I had my hair chopped off and now I look like something that fell out of the sixties and cannot find its way home. Lots of headbands and cardigans and mousse and volume. The only thing that this will improve about me is my baking skills. That or render me utterly un-domestic. I read Bob Dylan's Chronicles and gave up on reading Pynchon in delirium, especially since I apparently had lots of conversations with people that did not actually happen, mostly about crushed ice and diluted apple juice. I also had dreams that included baseball bats that I am very glad did not actually happen (or at least hopefully did not because then I would be dead and this is a rather bland afterlife). In two weeks I will be prancing around Trafalger Square and making obscure references to folk songs.

First wave of the familial invasion starts tommorrow, instead of Tuesday, so the house can be classified as a massive mess.  Instead of being productive, I sat in my room and wrote a horrible paper on "The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock" and read more T.S. Eliot than was probably healthy.  

My goal for the next week is to be out of the house as much as possible, and when not outside the house to stay in my room, playing music and reading books that my family would probably not approve of (i.e. anything that is not about thermocouples or sub-zero vapourization or something).  I think that there are only so many times that one can answer the question "Where are you going to college?" without going spare.  I had hoped to simply record my reply on a tape so that instead of talking I could press play and wander away instead of holding conversations, but my mother was not supportive, and as a consequence I can't find recording devices of any sort.  

The other thing that I will be asked with frequency is how my love life is going, while the rest of the family waits with baited breath in the wings to hear my response and then dissect it.  On this front, I am resolved to tell everyone that I am becoming a nun.  At this point, their innate dislike of most things Catholic will kick in and I will be left alone for the remainder of their visit.

Word of the Day: neurotic

Saturday I felt like a drag queen version of elsa schiaparelli.

Today I felt like a junkie.  (Thank you uncooperative veins)

Today I was also told that "The chains on your teeth'll hurt--but don't worry, they're just going to twist your tooth around 45 degrees" which was really reassuring.

Tommorrow I will have an extremely spiritual, amazing experience.

That sounds about right.

Lincoln is making me feel like a claustrophobe. Everyone knows everyone, and in my paranoia I feel that I will be discovered as knowing them all. Not that this would affect anything really, would it. But in my mind it would be the worst thing ever. No more anonymity. Probably just paranoia and bad luck--these people do not know or care who I know--but still unhelpful to leading a balanced, healthy lifestyle (which is my goal, dontchaknow). I'm supposed to keep a sleep and dream journal for psychology. I can't tell if this will be a sleeping weekend or not--anyway, there will still be the 5:00am waking up times that make me wish that I was well again. I need to get myself checked out--if it hasn't stopped by next week I am going to pay someone to stick me full of needles and tell me what is wrong with me. My doctors are there to give me diagnoses so that I don't have to make up excuses all by myself. Last weekend I fell in love with a city that is not mine at all. I was motivated enough when I came back to change the film in my camera, but then got too frustrated by having taken pictures of everything twice before and feeling too crotchety to flatter my friends by taking their pictures. I ended up looking through the massive folders of England on my computer and pinning all my hopes on an indistinct date three months from now. And as a product from obssessive past photo viewing: Hey, remember when they made me look like this? Um, now I guess I just pose next to fire hydrants (RED) and look awkward voluntarily:

my mother today at dinner: "if airfare is this cheap, it would be no problem getting you home if we still lived here while you went to the University of Chicago." despite the two huge ifs in that statement, the fact that the possibility of me in Chicago next year hasn't been totally ruled out just made me that much happier. eeeee.

Further proof that I've become too institutioalized for my own good:  today I signed a totally non-school related paper with my name and my student ID.  I turned it in and was surprised when they asked me what the numbers meant.

The across-the-street neighbours have had their trees invaded by grackels, and their children who come home in police cars have taken to shooting of guns to make them shut up.  This does happen, but only after immense rustling and burying of the gun-toting tormenters in piles of yellowred leaves.  And two seconds later the birds are at it again, and the shooting and rustling and cawing starts all over again.

I did fifty derivations and fell asleep four times this afternoon.  Accomplishment.

I've started driving a lot again--seven hours here, seven hours back tommorrow.  Then in two weeks, another round of it in another direction.  Minnesota is overcast and slightly cold, and I saw Carleton, as well as talk to thousands of Speech Kids who were there too.  Are they EVERYWHERE?  

I'm writing a lab report and seeing my family.  Woke up at 6:30, know I'm tired, so the answer presents itself in thousands of cups of tepid coffee, one after the other, all morning.  Since this house has no kitchen, actually making the coffee can sometimes be quite a feat.  Also, seeing as the house was built in the 1920s, the plumbing is doubtful, although the architechture is gorgeous, if a little stripped.

I never want to go back to Lincoln.  I'm ready to spend all my money on cheap booze and expensive drugs in Austria now.  Anyone want to split rent on a grotty flat with me?

Today I was reminded, brutally, of why I want to leave high school. Now. However, something brightened up my day considerably: Yes, the new Bob Dylan album came out. I am now very happy. V. v. happy indeed.

Today my car decided to give up the ghost (with no poise) at the end of a street.  Gliding to a stop, I'm alone but only decide to have a panicattack after I've been rescued to do cell phone calls and bright lights shining in through my back window.
The moon was fantastically bright and I scanned all the cars passing my locked window wondering if I knew anybody in them (maybe I did). 

At midnight my mother handed me a tube of medication creme and then headed downstairs to play piano.  My whole head is being drowned out by some unrecognizeable lament from our untuned piano--my mother also came home with a mandolin--we found a zither in the closet.  If my whole ouse collapses the cacophony of musical instruments will be deafening (a screaming comes across the sky--but not horrendous, simply deathly).

The moon has looked "apocalyptic" (according to reliable sources) for two days running.  As a result, I decided that I would cave to a sickness for the first time in 1 1/2 years yesterday and spent the day avoiding everyone, staying in bed with Yossarian, and, when I'd finished him, starting in on Scottish junkies.  I have decided that I have an aptitude for falling in love with fictional (and thus unattainable) men.  Also, the fact that some of the real people I know assure me that "one day you'll find someone to be cute with" only strengthen my resolve to have tragic one sided relationships with men who are figments of other people's imagination. Hurrah!

I also bought black leggings today.  They mistakenly made me think that I was graceful so I consequently fell down.

Word of the Day: pursue

Summer has regressed again from being a social-filled bubbly fun whirlwind to me just sitting around trying to hide from both the neighbours and being selective as to whom and what times I am avaliable.  Today I went to the library and fetched not only large amounts of Virgina Woolf and Salman Rushdie, but also a several thousand page book to four-year colleges, as prompted by my parents (who also insist that I sign up for my SAT II(s) now).  Apparently my procrastination has been nipped in the bud.  Ah well.

(Katy, you may skip the next section.  You've already heard it enough.)

I was also informed by my terribly nosy neighbour that since there will be <u>so many of us</u> graduating next year in our neighbourhood that she has decided to have a mass graduation party for all of us--in her house, because she has the tables (which are a short commodity?).  It would be me, known as Suzanne, two extremely active young gentlemen of the sports-like persuasion whose friends may or may not spike the punch, the odd, also sports inclined catholic boy from next door, and the southeat cheerleader from two houses down.  Thrilling to be sure.  I know it won't go through, but the very thought that it was proposed chills me to the bone.  If, by some fluke it does go through, everyone is cordially invited to come and act as stoned as humanly possible. 

There, a brief synopsis of what is or is not going on.

Tommorrow is the World Cup Final.  I need to get myself adopted by a family with a bigscreen television.

Went to go see The DaVinci Code last night, and I must say that I was astounded and outraged. I grew furious and could not contain my outbursts. Why, you ask? There was not proper document preservation. Supposedly precious documents from the time of Christ were kept, stacked on top of each other, behind glass sildey doors without temperature or humidity controls. AH! Yes, I think I have solidified my status as a total and complete nerd. This is why you don't take me to history movies. Overall, it was fairly good, with excellent shots of things that made me miss Europe (although I think I giggled through all of the "serious" bits due to inane dialouge). And now, off to a concert in Omaha over which my mother is going crazy, as she apparently thinks that we are fated to perish (she's filled me up with instructions and also given me her AAA card) on the way there. Or back. Or something.

Grades have come, so has the SAT score report; I took the ACT this morning, and the only thing expected of me is that I sit and wait until somebody somewhere send me back pieces of paper from College Board and---whoever does the ACT. Them. Junior year is over, but I can't quite deal with that yet--the idea of a clean (!!) locker (The masses of bottles extracted from my half--I had Lang after lunch and nowhere to put them); The idea of not getting mad at things in the darkroom (until next year); Not begging rides from completly random people to events throughout the city; And so on and so forth. So far, I've conducted a whirlwind love affair with Jack Kerouac, and am settling down to my new languid literary lover, Salman Rushdie. Any other suggestions as to what to read this summer? Summer school has started, and I have an abundance of persons who obviously do not know their own pant size, since not many of them wear garnments that are at all flattering to their body shape. Also, for the record, there is, in fact, a girl who is pregnant. Apparently, the stereotypes of who takes summer school gym classes have a basis somewhere. C'est la vie, I guess. I only have thriteen more days. Thirteen more. And so, we take compromising pictures of ourselves. With flowers. So it goes.

Words aren't coming easily, so let's just start by doing this by the numbers, shall we? Number of Standardized College Board Sponsored Tests taken this week: 3 Number of Regular Tests taken this week: 2 Number of Prom Dates that aren't going with me, after all: 4 Number of Random Pick-ups: 2 Number of Times Honked At: 5 Number of People who Now Share My Pain At Joining the very American We-Want-Orthodondia-Work-Done Club: 1 I just walked back from the SAT a few hours ago, and have just realized that prom is, in fact going to start in 5 and a half hours. To avoid actually having to deal with this, I'm going out to lunch with my mother when she finishes playing her new dulcimer and probably not going to return any phone calls. Prom and the attitude that "omgeverythingwillbeperfectthisisthebestnightofmylifeomgagain" has put the fact that we do not even have a decent dating pool here into an even harsher light. We do, perhaps, qualify for a dating birdbath. But only one that has been sitting out in the hot sun for two weeks while the owners are in Europe. But nevermind. I am done with this year's bout of AP tests, which is helpful to an extreme, although I do get to agonize about how I did until the third week in July, when the grades will be mailed to me (and when I will promptly shred them, most probably). To counteract the fact that the gestapo are now running the school, I've registered for university classes next fall. There goes my class rank. But, on the upside, I'll be allowed to walk freely among the buildings. That should be all, for you that do not see me ona regular basis. Tonight: I attempt the emulate Notes from Underground, at least to a small extent (i can't do it properly, as I am not Katy). Word of the Day: anachronism

walking across the grass at dusk is like walking over an aerial photograph of the Gobi desert.

The allure of Catholic churches is amazing; they pull you in and demand attention.  Magnetism (i can't be contracting catholicism--)


In other words, I am doing better in math and waiting until fourth quarter is donedonedone.  I think that I am not signed up for the right classes next year, but I really don't know.  We turned our third quarter physics project into a shoe rack.  It still has the hammer and sickle on the side.  I am rather proud of it myself.  


Word of the Day: dimming

So this weekend has been quite a mess of things, excluding (of course) sleep.

However, I've managed to squeeze in lots of homework, and a concert.  Having your father really want to go to Jenny Lewis and the Watson Twins is interesting.  But good as it provides a( a ride to omaha, b) tickets, and c) dinner.  V. v. good show, actually.

Other than that, my subconcious has been sending me the oddest nightmares--not like "AAAA!SCARYMONSTER!" sorts of things, but putting me in socially awkward situations, making me forget to do lang things, and also making me unable to distinguish whether things actually happened, or if they're just dreamed.  Thank you, unfathomable parts of my mind.

And now I get to spend all day working on physics quarter projects (which are pointless) and gossiping while I drill bits of metal into a plastic gutter (which really teaches me a lot about the priciples of physics. yes indeedy it does).

And so ends the informative ramble about Things That Happen In Susanna's Life.

Word of the Day: buffet

Its been one of those days/weeks/etc. However, we ended up defining those with Bob Dylan songs and felt slightly justified, if even more Dylan nerdy (if that was ever possible). We ended up at the fountains at the Union eating gyros and talking about everything in the world and more. I can't wait until I can actually legitimaly be on a campus. Or at least until they turn the fountains back on for the summer. On my way home, I was rounding the corner to my street, and counted fifteen robins, wet and puffed up from the rain. Earlier, I became sated with tortellini and pita bread along with old yearbook pictures and dancing to Highway 61 Revisited. Its days like this that make me feel like I am moving even though I am staying in the same place. I am getting travel-sick. However. We'll just see how things go. Word of the Day: persimmon

she was born in spring, and i was born too late blame it on a simple twist of fate /photonarcisissm last night I heard the rain while in bed the first time in ages a half-hour interview turned into a two hour mini-road trip I learned that pretentious smart girls don't get married at the end of French plays I also ended up attacked by a plastic tree and pretending to be a saint (However, that is the farthest into cathlicism I will go. that and giving things up for lent just because I want to see how it goes) Word of the Day: concave

I am not supposed to be awake right now.  But, seeing as I can't write like William Faulkner, I decided to wake up early and give it another go.  However, I've been up since about 3:30, prowling around my house and lying in my bed.  And not, in fact, writing like William Faulkner.  Apparently, I "stack too much".

mmmmm, insomnia.

My alarm is set for 5:15.  I'll start work then, then go to school early, do a physics lab, get math help, attend classes, take pictures during third period, figure out whats going on with the pictures after school, come home sometime, write two "papers", do all of my physics problems, and whatever lang I have to do.  I even wrote it all out on a to-do list on a pink sticky note.  It's been a while since I've done that.

anyway.

Word of the Day: tyrant

"The only way in which people will be able to opt out of the system is by giving up their right to travel abroad."
This was said by a certain Alistair Carmichael, the spokesman for the Lib Dems.

Its rather depressing, although countered by the highly amusing, and highly, well, British name.

"The world is full of obvious things which no one by any chance ever observes."
That would be Sir Arthur Conan Doyle.

And I'm done randomly quoting dead (and alive) white (or not as I have no idea about Alistair) males.

Really.

Mr. Koehn wouldn't be proud.  Thus, it is validated.

So today, I underwent a traumatizing experience. That's right, I got my hair crimped. Why? Winter Play, of course. So, if you want to see it, you should come to Lincoln East High School, go to the Auditorium, buy a reasonably priced ticket, and watch the show, either: Thursday at 7 pm Friday at 7 pm Saturday at 2 pm or 7 pm. It is not depressing and Russian and about horses. It is actually rather amusing, being The Odd Couple, by Neil Simon (female version). I wear lots of dime-store-blue eyeshadow. There, I feel as though I have done enough publicity. Cheers! Word of the Day: exempt

So, I've begun second semester with 4 new folders, a now somewhat organized locker, and a hell of a cold.  Which has been travelling at lightning speed to everyone I know.  And no one knows exactly where it started, but its definately was bad when it got to me.  It was worse when I gave it to my mother though--she's just finishing up three days of lying in bed making noises from pain/hallucination.

Its a fun time.

I've started CID and Buisness Law, and also realized that I actually have to do my homework, what with Math being first period and all that.  I have no normal size classes--5 classes are tiny, 1 is absurdly huge [I realize that this only adds up to six classes, but I really actually don't know what size Newspaper is].

I spent break going sinkhole hunting, eating cheesecake, and wandering around cemetaries where I am related to pretty much everybody bueried there before 1950.  Oh, the Ozarks.

Word of the Day: syllabus

Happy Twelfth Night!

That is pretty much the sole reason for my post.
That and the kings might actually arrive on time this year (le gasp!).

Word of the Day: sporadic

Katy and I, after I ate my lunch (ha! it was a granola bar, and the only thing i ate today before dinner), wanted to return to the library where our backpacks were languishing, guarded by the faithful Salome and Her Illegal Fruit Snacks.  However, between us and the library, an Administrator lay in wait, hoping to catch those troublemakers, walkie-talkie brandished high.  
We approached, cautiously, and attempted to slip by.  No dice, as he with his considerable girth was blocking the doorway.  Thus, the Interrogation began.

Administrator:  Where are you two going?
Katy: The Media Center
Me: [nearly at the same time] The Library
Administrator:  Well! Media Center or Library, you better get your stories straight and decide which one you're going to, or else you can't go through.  So, which one are you going to?
Me: [on the verge of hysteria, with exaggerated arm waving] Both!  At the same time!

Well, we were waved through.  Upon reaching the library/media center/destination I proceeded to attack people in the vague hopes that one of them would shower sedatives on me, but to no avail.  
Ah, School.  We're back.

Other than that, I am now legally able to get a driving license (although that won't happen anytime in the near future) and I also a received a How To Be Asian Birthday Kit from Madame Shuqiao that both brightened my day and brainwashed me (both good, although I may have a tendency to now be distracted by shiny objects and have an immense fondness for the colour red).

Two days until Epiphany!

Word of the Day: gilded

So, here it is:
Happy Christmas! So far, I have made peppermint cookies (the badly Saran Wrapped plate in above photo), gotten a Russian novel (also in above photo), and had a dicussion about how Tristan and Isolde would be ruined for those people that knew what actually happened (that girl up there on the left, namely). Sometimes, I really have to wonder about the family; when your father walks into the kitchen, presents your friend with a travel pack of keleenex as a chritmas present, then divulges that he just found it while cleaning out something or other. Feliz Navidad!

For the first time this week, I am starving at dinner time. This week was interesting, culminating with a wave of oh-wow-i-am-sick-and-about-to-faint at about lunchtime. I'm fine now. Completely and totally. I swear. However, after spending a semester carrying my books, my bag decided to stage a mutiny and the strapped ripped today. Hurrah. There is something wrong if your workload breaks your backpack. Perhaps its a physical manifestation about how everything else seems to be falling apart, but frankly I did enough analysis for a Cognard paper and so do not care to look into it further. There is only so much philosophy one can take. I've finished all my immensley pressing homework and so am going to bunk down tonight with tea and the Bob Dylan documentary. Because wallowing in the 60's for 3 1/2 hours hearing Dylan music is Not A Bad Way to spend a friday night. Especially when the world is away at a speech tournament (I was the only person at our sections of the lockers. A bit ridiculous, but I wish them all well today and tommorrow). Word of the Day: persuasion

"Hell is other people." 
--Sartre

Coming into Philosophy and seeing that written on the board nearly made me laugh aloud.

i have not long enough to write my lang paper, not enough time to finish everything else, and not enough energy to keep up with everybody's everythings.  Bah humbug.  Can someone please kidnap me and take me somewhere fairly isolated, where there are history and physics books, and no memorization of formulas and no humanity?  Thanks.

Word of the Day: empirical

[I didn't mean to sound terribly off--I am just tired and slightly on the overworked side.  Is anyone up for anything this weekend or next week?  Food is good]

[i need to up the temperature in this house.  When one gets goosebumps just by walking around....]

Apparently, I am a math problem.

I was forced into submission by way of the councelor today (should bbe a method adopted by the spanish inquisition).  However, in our own private act of rebellion, Salome, Shuqiao, and I did math homework instead of listening.  Wow.  We are SO bad.

I need to buy tights if I still want functioning legs by the end of winter.

I lost badly in ping-pong to my father.  (How can you be bad at ping-pong?!)  My mother was not here to witness this, as she went out "for a few drinks" with some people today after work and had not returned.  Actually, she just got back.  9:44 pm.  my worst fears that she would be sitting on a park bench at the bottom of a ditch getting frostbite were not confirmed.  However, we'll see what sort of state she's in when she gets inside.

Word of the Day: attachment

Today, after taking 35 minutes to do my physics retake test, I walked home (nothing out of the ordinary).
Everything was fine, except for the fact that as I was walking, the quintessential Ratty Blue Car pulls up.
Three boys inside.
Window rolls down.
"BITCH!
HEY BABY!"
laughter.
and they drive away.
ok.
whatever.
Maturity is never overrated.  It's just in short supply.
Psh.  I discard them.

I have once again assumed the duties of the only person in my family who is going to write christmas cards.
Two days ago I wanted to be in Spain.  Now I want to be in England.  

Registration for senior year tommorrow.  Currently, my schedule is two full semesters---with 10 classes each.  I think I will have to trim down some.  Any suggestions on what to take/not take?
Senior year.
WHAT? ARGH!
I haven't even registered for the SAT/ACT yet....

Word of the Day: truncated

Well, thanks to the snow outside and the immense cold, it properly feels like winter, so putting up advent calenders and a wreath does not feel awkward (no, we don't have a tree.  don't know when we'll get on either....).  I just returned from a <s>torture session</s> walk around Holmes Lake for an hour, and thus cannot feel my thighs or face.  I don't suppose they were very necessary in the first place?

I think that I shall go heat the mulled cider and consume more banana bread until I can neglect my homework no longer.  Or until I decide to watch the Bob Dylan documentary.

Anyone want to go sledding sometime soon?

Word of the Day: numb

Despite cancerous chemicals and freezing temperatures, I've been spending a lot of time in the darkroom. I'd like to say it was purely for fun, but its partly because I think that I very possibly have a not-so-wonderful grade in photography due to the rebellion of a camera that resulted in ruined film. However, I still find myself plunging my hands into the dektol, coating them with a white film that makes it look like I avoid lotion, developing prints that have to realtion to any project that I'm supposed to be working on. Oh, well. I finally have overcome my "I sound like a boy going through puberty" phase, which was thanks to an undefined illness. Although it appeared that certain people enjoyed my voice cracking every onetwothree when I opened my mouth. I've done writing and laundry, worn a scarf every day this week, and fogged up the windows of Erin's car (and yes, we did get weird looks from passing minivans--despite the fact that we were just sitting there). I've found out I have an A in math, I can't touch my nose with my tongue, and that some people would be far better as specimens in a Mason-Ball jar with air holes poked in the top. Today I ripped a seam in my coat, and the Pyromaniac of East has struck again; this time lighting a sweatshirt on fire in the Counceling Center hallway--why, yes, that is right in front of the campus security office. Well spotted (much better than campus security who apparently can't spot anything?). Walking down the hall you could almost smell the irony along with the smoke (which was horrid by the way. Good ventilation is apparently Not Necessary.) C'est la vie. Word of the Day: porpoise

Doing choreopoems wasn't too bad. However, going to see Harry Potter when I knew I should have been working on my homework and not really caring at all was fantastic (go see it. You know you want to). Salome and I squealed all the way back to her house. I think that both Hendrik and Danny were a little scared, but they were in the backseat, and I couldn't be troubled to look around. We moved yet another piece of historical furniture into the living room. This time its a postal sorting desk, originally from 1940, as the stamp on it states. Very solid. And also very, very heavy. You should come see it sometime, just to marvel at how weird were are. So working on that there philosophy paper, and feeling good about it. It could also be the fact that just today i discovered that we have Brewer and Shipley's "One Toke Over The Line". There's nothing quite like writing about Aristotle's Metaphysics concerning the soul and how St. Thomas Aquinas reconciled that with the Catholic Church while singing "One toke over the line, Sweet Jesus one toke over the line sitting downtown in the railway station one toke over the line" Try it sometime, kids. Trust me, you won't be dissapointed. Word of the Day: Aristotelian (oh come on, you knew it was coming)

just got home, and i'm a-putting off pre-calc. 
(yeah, the pictures will get posted.  I am just fiddling with lots of things now.)

I am really wondering why everybody thinks that I can fix everything.  In all honesty, I have no earthly idea where that sprang up from; I am not a repairer, I just don't get super-involved.  Love to get to the root of that; however, it goes on my to-do list.

I've been writing letters.  Although apparantly, some of them need 12 cents additional postage, hence i got them back with that nifty "return to sender" label on them.  Which raises the question:  isn't it just more work to have it go back through the mail to me, then back out again, rather than just sending it on its merry square-shped way (yes.  it was a square card.)?  But whatever--I concern myself not.

Winter has truly come--I've been wearing nothing but longsleeves for a week.  And my hat (yeah i made it.  boredom in the summer = lots of winter wear.  i just finished (another) scarf, this time for my mother.  I now have no knitting projects and my life is bleak).

Word of the Day: Truncate

P.S. got a new rilo kiley CD from homers.  which made me happy.  also my father just returned home, sans the cover on his bike helmet.  so if you see it, please return?!

I have been finding myself in the oddest situations lately.
I was accompanied by Katy, and we ended up searching for ingredients at the grocery store,

where we discovered that Shakespeare has started his own food buisness (what's next--Troilus and Cressida Chocolate [perfect for Valentine's day!]? Or perhaps Pericles Tuna Fish [Marketed with the simple "Yarr!"]). We then had a bonfire,

or at least our excuse for it--throwing leaves ona fire should count. We made smores and apinach and artichoke dip, managing to fry the blender on our way--spinach is vicious! The doorbell rang, and we added stephie to our group of miscreants. By a twisted set of circumstances, we ended up at Wal-Mart at midnight (ok, ok, 10:30).


Katy checked labels at the morgue shoe section, while Stephie modeled clothing from both the toddlers section, and others:


which begs the question--can it really be described as wal-mart style?

P.S. i need something other than photobucket--anyone, suggestions?

Well, I have officially (if somewhat indirectly) caused my second accident by walking home. Nothing serious either time, mind you--not even visible damage on either car--but still enough to make the drivers turn on their emergency blinkers, get out of their respective cars, and shamble over to inspect the vehicles and dart shady looks at each other, each poised with a cell phone in hand. I don't mean to cause these things, but being as pedestrian, I do like to get to my abode everyday (otherwise I would be sleeping at school which really is not an appetizing prospect). To do so, I must cross the street. Mind you, I always cross when the little light says WALK etc. etc., mostly because I do not want to end up as puree courtesy of an SUV. But occasionally, a vehicle will wish to turn while I am crossing. They (due to the traffic rules) must stop, as I have the right of way. I honestly feel bad about holding up traffic, and try to hurry across. I do, I do. But, apparantly, the mental processes of some drivers go along these lines "Despite the fact that all the cars in front of me are not moving and have their brake lights on does not mean that they are actually stopped, since the light is green. Therefore they must be moving and ohnoitsanothersolidcarthatisnotgoingtodisappear--" sqee-crunchcrash. Wince. And chaos ensues while I attempt to slink past on the sidewalk hoping NOT to be noticed by anyone. But in other news, there's always philosophy: Erin....POUNCE!! Oh poor bouncy-ball; you were unaware of the cruel hand fate had dealt you....

so. There were lots of weird going out and getting Oracle picture things. There were also grand adventures in construction areas with my partner in crime, Madame Joulie! We carved pumpkins. (why, yes, mine is the one that looks drunk. Don't ask me how these things happen.) And my dad got ahold of a wig. And oh yeah. That Halloween thing. Moi and moi's fellow flapper. Danny as....? Well, you can try to figure that out. The hottest Einstein I've ever seen (what woman can resist that mustache?!) [Seeing as all pictures including Gavin are of exhibitionist nature, they are to be purged of sight and (hopefully) mind. And most definately not incuded. Whyyyy was he allowed in front of the camera?!] We did get off with quite a haul. Including the communist Kit Kat Army. [Labels read Chairman Kit Kat and The Masses.] And despite all circumstances, all is well. [Even though I shan't be associating with the male sex for approximately 437 years. Are there any nunneries that haven't got anything to do with god?] Except for Mock Trial Tommorrow. And I have this horrible guilty feeling we had lots of practice today. That I am not attentding. Erm....

so i finished the paper.

despite my computer rebelling.

and sending me pop-ups that won't go away every 5 minutes.

now the printer is not working.

this is highly unfunny yet i am laughing.

why?!

there is something ironically marvelous about writing a SERN dealing with the fixed pivotal center of Americana while attending a football game.

P.S. Yeah, we won the game.  Hell has officially frozen over (as have my extremeties).  But I shall take it like a MAN.  And also drive like one.

So, I made one-acts, despite not checking in on Friday and Monday. Apparantly as the Math Teacher. After talking to Koesters, however, I have decided to nix it. I feel awful about it, but I know that I can't do one-acts on top of Mock Trial, on top of all my classes--my weekends are shot to hell as is; i am schduled to come to school on Halloween. However, I will do winter play, even if it kills me. [the only thing that makes me feel just an eentsy bit better is the fact that I wasn't to keen on the subject matter anyway] Now I'm just sitting at the kitchen table, immersing myself in pre-calc and letting the sounds oozing from the vynil records obliviate all else. The good things of today were: -Getting to school at 10:30. -My schdule: Photo Tech, AP Lang, and Newspaper. Who could ask for more? -Giving Kir her birthday chocolate and talking. -Tonight's prophesized dinner. And: Raking leaves barefoot in my front yard in a skirt. [Despite the fact that BJ greeted me with a "Hello,Woman of the Plains." But I disregard this.]

1:39 am.

Physics Problems: done.
APUSH Document Based Question Essay: finished.
Socratic Proof: complete.
Physics Current Event: terminado.
Physics Lab: Aw hell.
APUSH Reasearch for Debate: not this too?

Screw it.
I'm going to bed.
What's newspaper/lunch for if not to frantically finish my homework?

so i really need to start listening to announcements. Despite the fact that they always fall in either lang or newspaper, when i really would rather be doing other things. apparantly, they changed requirements for auditions. ah well. I want it to rain so that I can stand outside and wash the smoke out of my hair. Arriving home after getting a ride from a driver that smokes = awkward interrogations (in my defense, it was sprinkling and I don't have the money to pay for a new Pre-Calc book if this one gets ruined). If it is raining tommorrow at lunch, I think I will go outside and then come and drip on butler's floor. Anyone with me? I nearly got Sven to come with me today, but he was on another tirade about how we are un-normal (compared to his German friends, apparantly. I guess they don't use bananas as surrogate telephones during their lunch periods?). I want to dig something up. And also be somewhere sunny. If I explained this to the councelors as my long term career goals, I do not think that they would be pleased. However, it is their own damn fault for trying to make me think of what I want to do. "why are they called road alligators?" "maybe because if you run them over they kill you." Word of the Day: interrogation

Concerning the safety of the residents of Lincoln, Nebraska: After the 27th of December, 2005, drivers, pedestrians, and all forms of persons/animals that come near any roadways will be at an exceedingly high risk for their lives. So, yeah, I passed le driving exam! Muahahahahaha.... And I am making spinach and artichoke dip, not doing philosophy, and ignoring both my room cleaning tasks and physics. Now I just have to pretend that I am here again: And the random note of the day (well, yesterday actually): I have officially learned to change the oil in the truck. I have also learned that my arms are far too short for me to ever become a professional mechanic for big trucks. Maybe I could start a mechanics shop specializing in Vespas and other vehicles with easy to reach oil filters?

First Pre-Calc and Physics tests: Fab Second Pre-Calc and Physics tests: not so fab However, the new Franz Ferdinand CD has come into my life and given me direction again. Or at least given me something good to dance to. I'm taking my driver's test tommorrow. Shocking, I know.

today i officially fell asleep for the greater portion of first period.  sleep = bliss

go see Kiss Me Kate. East High. 7:00. v. v. good.

more later.

Word of the Day: ponderous

I have just returned from my first foray into non-LPS education this year.  That's right, Southeast Community College Driver's Education!  Thanks to the enlightening information bestowed upon me, I am ready to face the world.  What did I learn, you ask?  I learned.... Red means Stop.  Green means Go.

....
Why?!  Why meeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee?
However, it is nice to know that twice a week for two hours I will be able to have intellectual superiority over a roomfull of people.  Its not much consolation, but I take what I can get.  (Actually, there is a remarkably high percentage of not-insupportable people.  We'll just see if they remain that way after six weeks.)  Also, I was asked if I was on drugs.  Why do people ask me that?!  Why?!  Do I give off an aura of "hey check it out i just took some mind altering substance a few minutes ago"?  Psh.  Psh.

But yeah. 
I had too much fun with my first photography assignment for Newspaper.  And I used up another roll of film.  Anyone up for photographic expedition this weekend?

Word of the Day: pointer

The second week of school is winding down.  I've managed to start out my junior year with masses of homework and also the Orange Plague.  Fun times all round, eh?

However, I am managing well with the homework, and with Super-chow forcing orange juice down my throat I will soon recover from the plague or die trying.

I have been forced to remember what 6:15 in the morning looks like.  People may rave about the beauties of the sunrise, but the sun seems to lose some of its glory when it is rising as I am traipsing through a golf course getting the lower quarter of my pants soaked with dew.

Other than that--I got henna done on my hands! yay!

Wow, I think that perhaps I have even outdone myself on complete randomness.

LATER:
Just got back from a combination shoe shopping/motorcycle ride with my father.  Never tried it before?  you should!  its liberating (or something)

So, school's in a week.
I compensated by agreeing to go shopping with Erin and buying the world's Most Comfortable Pants in the name of "Things I Really Need I Swear Mum Really".

You find some interesting things by flipping through the Lincoln paper: In the article "Swaziland girls celebrate end of sexual activity ban": "During the ban, Swazi girls were instructed to wear the scarves as a sign of their chastity. If an umchwasho [banned-under 18] girl was approached for sex by a man, she was expected to throw her tassles at his homestead, obliging his family to forfeit a cow." So next time you are solicited by an unwanted male, throw a scarf at his house and you will become one cow richer! So other than that, life's been nice, although vaguley awkward. the whole summer-coming-to-an-end thing, I guess. My life is also further complicated with having to deal with 25 small hyper children at 8:00 every morning at the zoo. My foot still has not recovered from getting flattened by an obese child carrying a backpack full of books. Random thing learned lately: Yes, it is quite acceptable to cook pasta in a wok. With chopsticks. Thank you Super-chow. Word of the Day: quite
